items.title: Implementing changes to the Competition Act (Bill C-59)
items.author: Competition Bureau Canada
items.content:
<article>Transcript

Visual:

Title Card: Competition Bureau Canada / Bureau de la concurrence Canada – Implementing changes to the Competition Act

Speaker on-screen: Matthew Boswell, Canada’s Commissioner of Competition.

Audio:
The Government of Canada has recently made a series of important changes to the Competition Act. 
These changes give us stronger tools to take enforcement action and promote competition -- so that all Canadians can benefit from lower prices, better services, and more choice.   
Over the coming months, we will be updating our guidance to give clarity on how and when we’ll take action under the new provisions of the law.   
As a part of this process, we will be holding a series of public consultations.  

Visual: A group of 5 men and women speaking to each other around a table in an office setting.  The man on the left hands a stack of paperwork to the man in the middle. The scene then returns to Matthew.

Audio:
We’re hoping to hear a wide range of perspectives, and we’ll carefully consider all of the feedback we receive. 
In the meantime, we welcome any comments or suggestions that you’d like us to consider.   
These can be submitted through our new Guidance Feedback Form. 
We look forward to hearing from you on these important changes to competition law in Canada. 

Visual: End card: Competition Bureau Canada / Bureau de la concurrence Canada accompanied by the Canadian Flag Government Identifier.</article>

items.title: AI generated scams
items.author: Competition Bureau Canada
items.content:
<article>Artificial intelligence is an exciting tool that can help us in our everyday lives, but fraudsters can also use it to make their frauds even more convincing. If you believe you’ve come across misleading AI generated content, report it to the Competition Bureau. For more information, check out our consumer alert: The rise of AI: Fraud in the digital age: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2024/03/the-rise-of-ai-fraud-in-the-digital-age.html

Transcript

Title/Cover: AI generated scams 

Scene 1: Audio
Sam finds AI technologies helpful for work and school. 
 
Scene 1: Visual
Image on-screen: Visual shows a figure on sitting in a coffee shop on a computer.

Scene 2: Audio
But here’s the thing: Fraudsters can also use AI to target Canadians. 
 
Scene 2: Visual
Image on-screen: Visual changes to close-up of computer screen. On the screen is a social media website and a video pops up on screen.  
 
Scene 3: Audio
One day, Sam spots a sponsored ad with their favorite celebrity endorsing a miracle skin care product.
 
Scene 3: Visual
Image on-screen: The pop up video is enlarged. Visual of a celebrity figure appears on screen holding up a bottle. Stars appear around the bottle. 
 
Scene 4: Audio
Sam is sold and ready to give it a try.
 
Scene 4: Visual
Image on-screen: Visual changes to the figure looking at their computer screen and holding up a credit card. The figure focuses on the computer screen. 
 
Scene 5: Audio
But after paying closer attention, they realize the person in the ad is a fake. Fraudsters can use AI to make fake images, audio, or videos of real people to sell you phony products.
 
Scene 5: Visual
Image on-screen: Visual changes to the computer screen. The word “FAKE” appears next to the celebrity figure. The video zooms out to reveal the celebrity figure in the video is a puppet being controlled by a figure wearing a hoodie. The stars on screen fall. 
 
Scene 6: Audio
Always pay close attention to content you see online before handing over your hard-earned money. 
 
Scene 6: Visual
Image on-screen: Visual changes to the figure looking at the computer screen focused.

Scene 7: Audio
If you come across deceptive content, report it to the Competition Bureau.

Scene 7: Visual
Image on-screen: Visual of the Competition Bureau’s website on a laptop computer animates on screen with text that reads “Competition Bureau Canada”. Text that reads “Complaint Form” animates at the top of the computer screen in the search bar.</article>

items.title: Fake Online Reviews and Subscription Traps
items.author: Competition Bureau Canada
items.content:
<article>As social media and online shopping have become ever-present in our lives, we are increasingly exposed to the risk of being targeted by fraudsters. If you believe you have come across fake online reviews or have been misled by a free trial offer, report it to the Competition Bureau: https://competition-bureau.canada.ca/contact-competition-bureau-canada/complaint-form

Transcript

Title/Cover: Fake Online Reviews and Subscription Traps 

Scene 1: Audio
Meet Alex.
 
Scene 1: Visual
Image on-screen: Visual shows a figure on screen sitting sideways on a chair in their kitchen. The figure is browsing the internet on their smartphone.
 
Scene 2: Audio
While browsing the internet, they found a streaming service with a one-time payment for exclusive content. 
 
Scene 2: Visual
Image on-screen: Visual changes to close-up of smartphone. Visual of an ad for a streaming app with 50K 5-star ratings with animated text that reads: “SeriousFlicks, Find Exclusive Shows Here”. Visual of the figure's index finger tapping the "Reviews" button on-screen. 
 
Scene 3: Audio
The reviews were great, so they signed up.
 
Scene 3: Visual
Image on-screen: Visual represents scrolling through a list of 5 star reviews and the figure's index finger tapping on the "Subscribe" button on-screen. 2 green dollar signs appear. 
 
Scene 4: Audio
They soon discovered the service was lousy and the reviews were fake.
 
Scene 4: Visual
Image on-screen: Visual changes to the figure visibly frustrated while shaking the smartphone. Visual changes to the smartphone screen with a buffering animation overtop a stream. Visual changes to the list of reviews with the word "FAKE" appearing next to all of them. 
 
Scene 5: Audio
And to their surprise, they had an ongoing subscription they never agreed to.
 
Scene 5: Visual
Image on-screen: Close up of the smartphone and the figure's index finger repeatedly tapping the unsubscribe button. 
 
Scene 6: Audio
This can happen to anyone.
 
Scene 6: Visual
Image on-screen: Visual changes to the figure looking at their phone visibly angry. 
 
Scene 7 Audio
The Competition Bureau enforces laws against deceptive marketing practices. If you suspect deceptive ads, report them to us.
 
Scene 8 Visual
Image on-screen: Visual of the Competition Bureau’s website on a laptop computer animates on screen with text that reads “Competition Bureau Canada”. Text that reads “Complaint Form” animates at the top of the computer screen in the search bar.</article>

items.title: Cryptocurrency Investment Fraud
items.author: Competition Bureau Canada
items.content:
<article>Investment fraud, including cryptocurrency fraud, takes many forms, but they all have one thing in common – the big lie that you can make tons of fast cash! If you believe you have been misled or think you’ve seen a cryptocurrency investment fraud, report it to the Competition Bureau: https://competition-bureau.canada.ca/contact-competition-bureau-canada/complaint-form

Transcript 

Title/Cover: Cryptocurrency Investment Fraud 

Scene 1: Audio
Meet Jo, like many Canadians…

Scene 1: Visual 
Image on-screen: Visual shows a figure on screen sitting sideways on a chair in their living room. The figure is scrolling through social media feed on their device.

Scene 2: Audio
…they’re tempted by cryptocurrency’s fantastic financial potential.

Scene 2: Visual 
Image on-screen: Visual changes to close-up of scrolling, zoom in on a flashy investment ad with animated text that reads: “400% return in 2 weeks! Cancel anytime. INVEST NOW before it’s too late.” Visuals of crypto currency symbols display near the bottom of the screen. Hand animates into frame and a finger presses on the “INVEST NOW Before it’s too late” button.

Scene 3: Audio
Seduced by promises of high profits and guaranteed returns, Jo takes the “plunge.”

Scene 3: Visual 
Image on-screen: Visual of the figure holding their mobile phone in one hand and in the other hand, their credit card to transfer funds. Animated text on the right side appears “- $15,000” in red with an arrow pointing down to animated crypto currency symbols to indicate that they are investing real money in cryptocurrency on the fraudulent platform.

Scene 4: Audio
But over time, Jo will realize that online ads exaggerated potential earnings and their guarantees were fake.

Scene 4: Visual 
Image on-screen: Visual of an arrow rises through graph with five-star reviews animate below with text that reads “Just made $10k in a week! That’s totally legit. $$” and text that reads “The ultimate crypto investment solution!!!”. As the visual of the arrow on the graph continues to rise, the word “FAKE” animates over the graph and gets bigger and smaller a few times as a alert warning to the viewer. 

Scene 5: Audio
In the world of cryptocurrency…

Scene 5: Visual 
Image on-screen: Visual of the figure’s index finger clicking on a button with on screen text that reads “WITHDRAW”. 

Scene 6: Audio
…fraudsters are exploiting your lack of knowledge...

Scene 6: Visual
Once clicked, the button changes to red with animated text that reads “FAILED” on screen

Scene 7: Audio
 …with deceptive tactics like phony reviews and fake celebrity endorsements.

Scene 7: Visual
Image on-screen: Scene changes to a close-up of the figure looking down at their mobile phone with a surprised expression on their face. Their expression quickly changes to a frown discovering that their money disappeared, they cannot withdraw the cryptocurrency they thought they purchased, and they have been defrauded.

Scene 8: Audio
If you come across misleading investment ads report them to the Competition Bureau.

Scene 8: Visual
Image on-screen: Visual of the Competition Bureau’s website on a laptop computer animates on screen with text that reads “Competition Bureau Canada”. Text that reads “Complaint Form” animates at the top of the computer screen in the search bar.</article>
